thread.title: Kate Middleton and William's underground extension at Kensington which includes 'ceremonial dress display'
thread.title_full: Kate Middleton and William's underground extension at Kensington which includes 'ceremonial dress display'

author: Lucy Clarke-Billings
title: Kate Middleton and William's underground extension at Kensington which includes 'ceremonial dress display'
text:
News Kate Middleton and William's underground extension at Kensington which includes 'ceremonial dress display' The mega-expansion will provide more than 1,500 square metres of extra space over three floors - transforming the historic building's grade I-listed Orangery Share Kensington Palace has been home to the royal family since the 17th Century (Photo: Getty) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Kate and William's plans for an enormous underground extension at Kensington Palace have been revealed - and it includes a 'ceremonial dress display; 
The royal young family will move to London full-time in the autumn after Wills ends his two-year pilot's job with East Anglican Air Ambulance. 
The mega-extension, which will provide more than 1,500 square metres of extra space over three floors. The underground expansion will allow staff to be moved and palace suites to be freed up for the Duke and Duchess, Princess Charlotte and Prince George. 
It will transform the historic building's grade I-listed Orangery. 
Kensington Palace has been home to the royal family since the 17th Century. 
The local council, Kensington and Chelsea, has restricted residential two-storey basements because of the disruption they create but officials will probably ‘make an exception’ for the royal development, according to the Daily Mail. Read More 'No ring, no bring!': Pippa Middleton 'cunning plan' to block Meghan Markle from her wedding Prince George and Princess Charlotte will be settling into the palace this autumn (Photo: Getty) A planning application has been put forward by Historic Royal Palaces, the charity which looks after the state apartments at the palace (Photo: Tim Graham) 
The 165-foot basement, which is currently used as a restaurant by those visiting the palace, will become home to some of the palace's 100 staff. 
The extension will also be used to house a ceremonial dress collection. 
The planning application says: "The addition of a basement storey is required to allow for the accommodation of administration which must necessarily be moved out of rooms leased from the Royal Household in Kensington Palace." 
A council decision on the proposal is expected by the end of next month. Like us on Facebook
